The idea of universal moral truths is not meant to suggest that all cultures have the same moral beliefs or that some cultures are necessarily wrong or inferior to others. Instead, universal moral truths refer to principles or values that transcend different cultures and societies, such as human dignity, respect for life, justice, and fairness.

It is not necessarily helpful or productive to approach cultural diversity through the lens of deciding whose morals are right or wrong. Instead, we can approach cultural diversity by respecting differences and recognizing the right of different cultures to practice their beliefs and values, as long as they do not violate the basic principles of human dignity and respect.

In cases where cultural practices or beliefs violate universal moral truths, such as practices that promote violence or discrimination, it is important to challenge them and strive to change them. But, when engaging in discussions or debates, people must avoid imposing their moral beliefs on others or suggesting that their value system is superior to others.

Instead, to navigate through immense cultural diversity, we can focus on common values and principles that underlie different moral beliefs and practices. These common values, such as respect, honesty, compassion, fairness, and empathy, can help to identify shared perspectives and promote mutual understanding and respect.

In summary, universal moral truths refer to values and principles that transcend different cultures and societies. Rather than deciding whose morals are right or wrong, we can approach cultural diversity by respecting differences, recognizing the right to practice different beliefs and values, and focus on common values that promote mutual understanding and respect.
